sub_title: Public International Law LL.M at Leiden University
summary:
I am Italian and Iranian raised in Toronto and alumni of the University of Toronto, St. Michaels College with a double-major in Political Science and History. 

Currently, a masters law student in Public International Law and a human rights researcher with three years of experience working with human rights organizations. I aspire to be a barrister with an interest in international dispute settlement, international criminal law and international humanitarian law. 

In law school at the University of Essex, I led two teams running open-source investigation projects in a student based unit for Amnesty International conducted on Palestine and Lebanon and went on to become Manager of the Evidence Lab in my final year of law assisting on several OSINT investigations including contributing to UN Commissions of Inquiry. As Co-Founder, I pioneered the 10th site of an entrepreneurship and micro-enterprise program for Congolese youth in the Democratic Republic of Congo.

profile_positions.description:
Amnesty International’s Evidence Lab uses digital tools and techniques to find evidence of human rights abuses. The Digital Verifications Corps (DVC) is a network of students who authenticate videos and images to investigate and document suspected violations of international human rights and humanitarian law, around the world. Key techniques utilities include discovery across multiple social media platforms, satellite imagery analysis, geolocation, and content verification. 

My open-source research skills have contributed directly to the findings of UN Commissions of Inquiry and the development of a strategic litigation case prepared in collaboration with the Open Society Justice Initiative (OSJI).

- Co-managed and trained 27 volunteer student researchers working human rights investigations for Amnesty International and UN bodies
profile_positions.title: Digital Verifications Corps Manager

profile_positions.description:
In my second year of law school, I managed two teams each of roughly 5 students with a diverse range of skills, backgrounds and experience levels. As project leader, I managed both teams as we collect, organize, verify and catalogue openly sourced visual evidence for our partner, Amnesty International.

- Manage and integrate team-building exercises into research investigation work session to support the mental and emotional needs of both myself and all team members
- Manage the team tasks while training each member on open-source investigation techniques such as, learning how to use terrain view on Google Earth Pro, geolocation of both urban and rural areas, using SunCalc to determine the time of day with shadow-imagery.
- Design project workflow and methodology, including assigning roles, creating spreadsheets, making a list of search terms, and coordinating team members to collect contact related to the event on certain social media platforms
- Perform advanced geolocation of collected images or videos evidence, including in areas with limited satellite imagery and street view.
profile_positions.title: Project Leader

profile_positions.description:
As a researcher on the Crisis Response team, a team dedicated to investigating war crimes and serious violations of human rights in emergency situations all over the world.

I worked directly with the Senior Crises Adviser on 13,755 testimonies which I had to sort through and collect all evidence of state surveillance, electronic surveillance, in-person surveillance and even at-home police monitoring or forced participation.
- I was also responsible for conducting an open-source investigation to collect more evidence of all types of surveillance and organize it into a spreadsheet; reporting several details attached to each piece of media including specific details of the victims mentioned in the blogs, articles or testimonies. I compiled a dataset including 52 pieces of media on this topic.
- I worked alongside the Special Advisor for Remote Sensing in the Evidence Lab at Amnesty International to cross-reference a dataset given to me with over 100 locations located by satellite imagery. The purpose was to precisely locate and map out where the human rights abuses took place.
- I collected a spreadsheet with 40 pieces of media using open-source investigation which matched the locations given to me in the dataset. Each input included a detailed recording of each source, event, including summaries as well.
profile_positions.title: Intern

profile_positions.description: In my first year of law school, I began volunteering using open-source investigative techniques including satellite imagery analysis and geolocation to gather and analyze evidence of human rights violations; tools included Truly Media, Google Maps, Google Earth Pro, and Sun Calculator; work was integrated into investigative reports by Amnesty International and UN bodies

volunteer_experiences.description:
Legal Aid Ontario is a publicly funded and publicly accountable non-profit corporation, responsible for administering the legal aid program in the province of Ontario, Canada

Volunteer in the Refugee Law office assisting two refugee lawyers on cases and working with clients:

- Attend hearings, conduct relevant case-by-case country research
- Conduct client surveys to collect information in regards to clients participating in remote hearings

My work in the clinic is directed towards providing free-of-charge legal advice to clients in the local area, particularly I have focused on property law, contract law, and family law. 

- I was trained extensively on the etiquette of conducting client interviews and the appropriate behaviour in a professional workspace. I was taught how to correctly draft legal advice letters professionally. I was also trained on how to handle uncomfortable or difficult situations when dealing with clients that are entering the clinic on a walk-in basis. 
- In my role, I conduct client interviews under the supervision of a clinic staff member along with another student volunteer.
- In meetings, I may write an attendance note including detailed meeting minutes or conduct the interview questions to inquire more about the client, their issue, and the legal matter at hand. As a team, the student volunteer and I provide a legal advice letter to the supervisor within 7 days and a final draft to the client within 30 working days. I have worked with six clients so far and continue working in the clinic.
- As part of the clinic, I also took on project work where I volunteered at Refugee Action (an immigration law clinic) by observing interviews between legal aid workers and refugee/asylum seekers. Afterwards, I assisted in research and administrative work for the relevant applications.
- I participated in the Open Justice Project where I attended virtual hearings and I commented on my experiences in the courtroom and whether I agree/disagree with the judgments given.

Student volunteer tasked with observing interviews between legal aid workers and refugee/asylum seekers. Afterwards, I assisted in research and administrative work for the relevant applications. 

- tasked with researching certain issues relating to asylum seekers application/application status in the country
- helping clients understand certain aspects of their applications that were confusing or legally complicated
- helping to fill and organize certain areas of clients application forms
- managing client in face-to-face interviews and acting as emotional support in very stressful situations

I learned a lot of information about the status of several refugees and the complexity of the UK immigration system.

The Congo Leadership Initiative (CLI) is an international non-profit organization leading entrepreneurship and micro-enterprise programs in the Democratic Republic of Congo and has launched over 500 small business since its founding in 2010. Independently, I built a virtual team that I manage with international students where I organize meetings and, assign roles and responsibilities to each team member to help build the 10th site in Nyantende. As the Program Co-Director of the site in Nyantende I hold the following responsibilities:

- Working alongside Program Co-Director, Spencer Goodwin to facilitate the needs of the program and organizing yearly and monthly budget plans
- Dealing with and implementing the values and morals aligned with CLI and working with the Founder, Nathaniel Houghton to co-ordinate the needs of building our site in Nyantende, such as certain roadblocks in lack of access to communication with leaders on the grounds and how to get around them.
- Creating and signing off on employment contract to local Program Facilitator in Nyantende, also negotiating salaries and responsibilities to both leaders.
- Drafting application forms to be co-ordinates with local leaders to ensure the needs of both CLI and the applicants are met.
- I am responsible and signed onto local bank accounts as Program Co-Director in the DR Congo.
- Building a campaign, using Fundrazr, including information about our team, the purpose, aim and goals of the campaign, and lots of information about CLI itself and the need for the program in Nyantende.
- Mobilizing potential donors through our personal networks and collecting their emails, generating email addresses into MailChimp and sending campaign alerts, holidays emails, event emails.
-  Advertising the campaigning events on social media platforms to raise funding and track attention.

volunteer_experiences.description:
A charity organization that raises funds to enrol children in local primary education. Founder of the chapter and created a student-led team that ran on-campus events to raise money and educate fellow students about the urgency to spread awareness of the growing gap in access to education. The campus group is still running and raised $1,000 in 2020.

- Built a team of student volunteers and registered ourselves as an official club at the University of Toronto, St. Michael's College campus.
- Published an article in our campus newspaper after our club registration to engage fellow students and gain attraction towards the importance of the Nyantende Foundation to our peers.
- Organized tasks and roles to 4 student members: scribe, two Treasurers, Vice President, and myself.
- Ensured the success of the charity club after my graduation.
- Planning future charity and events and unique and interesting ways to raise fundings from our fellow students.
Taught young children-adults wakeboarding, water skiing and, wake surfing. Obtained an Ontario boating license, CPR training, Red Cross Bronze training.
